case_vignette: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of lesions on her left arm. She first noticed them 3 months ago and they have grown larger since that time. She has not had any pain or pruritus in the area. She has a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, which was treated with mastectomy and radiation therapy 27 years ago. Since that time, she has had lymphedema of the left arm. Physical examination shows extensive edema of the left arm. There are four coalescing, firm, purple-blue nodules on the left lateral axillary region and swelling of the surrounding skin.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Based on the given symptoms, both Thrombophlebitis (inflammation of a vein, often causing a hard, tender lump) and Angiosarcoma (a rare and aggressive cancer that forms in the inner lining of blood vessels) are possibilities. However, the presence of a firm, purple-blue bump that has grown over a significant period of time, along with arm swelling, raises the suspicion of Angiosarcoma. However, it is essential to consider other possible causes, such as Thrombophlebitis, which can also present with similar symptoms.
